p: In X. laevis, body size predicted jump force ( t = 2.11, P = 0.044) and individual identity explained part of the variance (standard deviations: intercept, 0.21; residuals, 0.29). Individuals measured at a test temperature of 23°C had a 19% higher jump force compared to individuals measured at a high temperature ( t = 3.20, P = 0.002; Fig. 1D), this independently of their acclimation treatment (acclimation *test: X 2 = 0.92, P = 0.34).
